thag10.6:1.1: In order to go on retreat,
thag10.6:1.2: a monk should stay in lodgings
thag10.6:2.1: Having gathered scraps from rubbish heaps,
thag10.6:2.3: and making an outer robe from them,
thag10.6:2.4: one should wear that coarse robe.
thag10.6:3.2: a mendicant should walk for alms
thag10.6:4.1: They should be content even with coarse food,
thag10.6:4.2: not hoping for lots of flavors.
thag10.6:4.3: The mind that’s greedy for flavors
thag10.6:6.3: an astute person would not speak overly long
thag10.6:6.4: in the midst of the Saṅgha.
thag10.6:8.1: Expert in the arising of thought,
thag10.6:8.2: they would grasp well the pattern of the mind.
thag10.6:8.3: They would be devoted to practicing
thag10.6:8.4: serenity and discernment at the right time.
thag10.6:9.1: Though endowed with energy and perseverance,
thag10.6:9.3: a wise person would not be too sure of themselves,
thag10.6:9.4: until they have attained the end of suffering.
thag10.6:10.1: For a mendicant who meditates in this way,
